List of 10 Best Mig Welder

It is widely used in different industries and sectors as it accounts for more than 50% of almost all weld metal that is deposited. What is Mig Welding?

Metal inert gas ( MIG ) welding is a type of arc welding technique which uses continuously uses solid wire electrode that is heated and fed into the weld pool via a welding gun.

In this case, the two metals or materials are melted together to form a joint between them. The gun inserts a shielding gas along with the electrode helping to protect the weld pool from airborne contaminants and impurities.

For the most part, we are done with the theory of MIG welding let us tell you its few applications. Generally MIG welding is widely used in most industry sectors and accounts for more than 50% of all weld metal deposited.

AS compared to MMA, MIG has the advantage in terms of flexibility, deposition rates and suitability for mechanization and production.

Hence, it should be noted that while MIG welding is ideal for splashing metal, a high degree of expertise is demanded from the MIG welder.

Altogether, The newbies should not feel disappointed because we have done many days of research to shortlist list 10 best MIG welders that are best suited for both hobbyists and professionals.

The Hobart handler 140 is a dynamic, trustable, power oriented and easy to use piece of equipment that is also remarkable value for the price it is available in.

Built under the name Hobart it ensures quality along with durability, it will not be wrong to say that Handler 140 is Hobart’s most popular MIG welder. It operates on standard 115V of domestic current.

As mentioned earlier the Handler 140 is an allrounder and perfect for the user who wants to work on auto body, household repairs, farm projects or yard art projects or simply for DIYs.

The Hobart 140 is a welding unit that provides nicely compacted MIG/flux core welding processes. Its popularity and simplicity can be comparable to many other models out there but they are costing more money—yet it delivers a respectively strong power of 140A.

To sum up, t this dynamic unit is one of the best MIG welders you will find in the welding market. This unit provides a duty cycle of 20%@90 amperes, certainly more than enough for everyday domestic DIY metal-involving welding chores and projects.

This MIG unit can weld items that are extremely thin for example only 24-gauge in thickness but also items that are quite a thick example: ¼ inch in thickness.

In fact, the Handler is the best choice for construction, maintenance, home repairs, farm use, rental shops, auto body work environments and every other welding task around the world.

Apart from this, let’s discuss Hobart 140’s weight. It is not as heavy in weight (compared to many professional welding units readily available in the market), hence making it easy to transport and carry around, especially if you will be using the unit as part of your wayfaring work routines.

Furthermore, it also does not take up too much space in your work van or truck or work station—and as welders all of us are aware of the fact that how important it is not to overload a work truck or station.

Buyer’s Guide: Choosing the Perfect Mig Welder

If you are still confused and haven’t made any mind then give this part a read. Subsequently, we have provided you with following “things to keep in mind” while buying the perfect MIG welder for you.

Price

Always keep your budget your first priority while looking for the most suited welder for yourself. We kept your budget in mind and chose 10 economical MIG welders but it does not mean you will get cheap quality MIG welders. Admittedly the units we chose give a variety of features that are best suited for all types of welders.

Usability

No matter how good a MIG welder is you need something which is easy to control. You know your welding skills better than us so it is totally your call to decide which welder will be easy for you to use and control and provide quality results.

Tasks needed to be done

Different welders work best on different types of materials. Some give best result on chrome-moly, some give fine weld on aluminum joints and some are efficient with steel. While buying a MIG welder keep in mind that will it be appropriate for the type of material you want to use it for.

Welding type

Although this article is all about best MIG welders as a sincere guide it is obligatory on us to tell you that different welders offer different types of welding techniques. Before buying a welder check if this welder is compatible for the type of welding technique you want to use.

Quality

Don’t buy a MIG just because it is cheap. Never compromise on quality. Firstly Check out the reviews and features of the unit you want to buy.

Duty cycles

The duty cycle is the percentage of how long can you use a welder before it overheats. Basically, a 5 or 10-minute period work efficiency (depending on the welder being used) that you can weld before the welder overheats. For example, if a welder has a 20% duty cycle at 80 amps over 8 minutes, then the welder can be operated continuously at 80 amps for 2 minutes before it needs a 2-4 minute break.

Gas vs less Gas

MIG welders need some type of shielding gas to keep oxygen away from the weld to avoid contamination.

The choices available for MIG welders are gas shielded (oxygen is displaced by an inert or semi-inert gas mixture contained in a bottled container) and flux-cored wire (where a protective covering is formed by a material included in the wire itself).

Both have pros and cons for each type of welding, but gas shielded is by far a better method to use.

FAQ’s

Aluminum is a tricky metal to weld with a MIG welding machine because it takes more heat than mild steel or other MIG friendly metals.

The minimum aluminum thickness you should attempt is roughly 14 gauge to 18 gauge. You’ll need a TIG welder for any metal or material thinner than that.

The most amazing fact about MIG welding is that it can be done on a variety of metal types, including stainless steel, mild steel, carbon steel, magnesium, aluminum, copper, nickel, bronze, silicon and many other alloys.

MIG welder is a type of welder that uses an easier type of welding technique for newcomers to learn. MIG welding is actually divided into two different types of welding techniques. The first technique uses bare wire and the second flux core.

Conclusion

It is time to conclude our article, we will be proud to know if you chose the best MIG welder for yourself from the above mentioned list. Therefore, we have keenly mentioned all the pros and cons, specifications, in depth product description of each MIG welder, and a critical comparison of the top-notch MIG welders for you.

Now, the clock is ticking buy a good MIG welder for you before it gets out of stock.
